It had been the first night of Procedure Anaconda. A special operations heli-copter was about to drop away from Roberts and the rest of his / her reconnaissance team when it was hit by rocket propelled grenades. The grenades don't detonate but they punctured the fuselage and ruptured gas lines that control the helicopter. It lurched and the tail gunner dropped out but has been caught by his / her safety harness. Roberts deposit his weapon and also pulled the gunner into the helicopter. But it lurched once more and Roberts, who was not really wearing a safety control, fell to the ground -- without his weapon.That helicopter limped absent and a second one had been hit by equipment gun fire. One commando was shot deceased and fell to the floor, still clutching his or her weapon.According to this account, reports Abc News National Safety Correspondent David Martin, Roberts crawled over to the lifeless commando, grabbed his tool, opened fire on the machine gun, stored firing until he or she ran out of bullets, then stood up and threw his / her grenades. That's when he was shot and murdered. Overhead an unmanned reconnaissance drone viewed as the al Qaeda fighters dragged off Roberts' system. Not knowing if he or she was dead or perhaps alive, a save force was sent in after him but was immediately pinned down by mortar and small arms fire. When they finally recovered Roberts' body, the recovery force had endured five more lifeless and 11 injured. For Americans it turned out the worst single day of the war inside Afghanistan, although officers declare Roberts could receive the Medallion of Honor if this type of version of events could be verified.To do that, your military has hired an officer to restore the entire battle by interviewing every jewellry who was there and revisiting the ground exactly where Roberts died. Fowler reported the information at this week's annual achieving of the American Diabetes mellitus Association in San Diego."What didn't surprise people was that full soft drink use had been linked to overweight as well as obesity," Fowler shows WebMD. "What was surprising had been when we looked at people only drinking diet regime soft drinks, their probability of obesity was even greater."In fact, when the scientists took a closer look in their data, they learned that nearly all the obesity risk from carbonated drinks came from diet sodas."There was a 41 percent increase in risk of obesity for every can or perhaps bottle of diet soft drink a person uses each day," Fowler states.More Diet Drinks, More Weight GainFowler's team checked out seven to eight years of data about 1,550 Mexican-American and non-Hispanic white Americans aged 25 to 64.
